segment.source: Performance Guidance for Application Virtualization 5.0
segment.target: Performance Guidance for Application Virtualization 5.0

segment.source: Performance Guidance for Application Virtualization 5.0
segment.target: Performance Guidance for Application Virtualization 5.0

segment.source: Performance Guidance for Application Virtualization 5.0
segment.target: Performance Guidance for Application Virtualization 5.0

segment.source: Learn how to configure App-V 5.0 for optimal performance, optimize virtual app packages, and provide a better user experience with RDS and VDI.
segment.target: Learn how to configure App-V 5.0 for optimal performance, optimize virtual app packages, and provide a better user experience with RDS and VDI.

segment.source: Implementing multiple methods can help you improve the end-user experience.
segment.target: Implementing multiple methods can help you improve the end-user experience.

segment.source: However, your environment may not support all methods.
segment.target: However, your environment may not support all methods.

segment.source: You should read and understand the following information before reading this document.
segment.target: You should read and understand the following information before reading this document.

segment.source: Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0 Administrator's Guide
segment.target: Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0 Administrator's Guide

segment.source: App-V 5 SP2 Application Publishing and Client Interaction
segment.target: App-V 5 SP2 Application Publishing and Client Interaction

segment.source: Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0 Sequencing Guide
segment.target: Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0 Sequencing Guide

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Some terms used in this document may have different meanings depending on external source and context.
segment.target: Some terms used in this document may have different meanings depending on external source and context.

segment.source: For more information about terms used in this document followed by an asterisk review the Application Virtualization Performance Guidance Terminology section of this document.
segment.target: For more information about terms used in this document followed by an asterisk review the Application Virtualization Performance Guidance Terminology section of this document.

segment.source: Finally, this document will provide you with the information to configure the computer running App-V 5.0 client and the environment for optimal performance.
segment.target: Finally, this document will provide you with the information to configure the computer running App-V 5.0 client and the environment for optimal performance.

segment.source: Optimize your virtual application packages for performance using the sequencer, and to understand how to use User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) or other user environment management technologies to provide the optimal user experience with App-V 5.0 in both Remote Desktop Services (RDS) and non-persistent virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI).
segment.target: Optimize your virtual application packages for performance using the sequencer, and to understand how to use User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) or other user environment management technologies to provide the optimal user experience with App-V 5.0 in both Remote Desktop Services (RDS) and non-persistent virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI).

segment.source: To help determine what information is relevant to your environment you should review each section’s brief overview and applicability checklist.
segment.target: To help determine what information is relevant to your environment you should review each section’s brief overview and applicability checklist.

segment.source: App-V 5.0 in stateful non-persistent deployments
segment.target: App-V 5.0 in stateful non-persistent deployments

segment.source: This section provides information about an approach that helps ensure a user will have access to all virtual applications within seconds after logging in.
segment.target: This section provides information about an approach that helps ensure a user will have access to all virtual applications within seconds after logging in.

segment.source: This is achieved by uniquely addressing the often long-running App-V 5.0 publishing refresh.
segment.target: This is achieved by uniquely addressing the often long-running App-V 5.0 publishing refresh.

segment.source: As you will discover the basis of the approach, the fastest publishing refresh, is one that doesn’t have to actually do anything.
segment.target: As you will discover the basis of the approach, the fastest publishing refresh, is one that doesn’t have to actually do anything.

segment.source: A number of conditions must be met and steps followed to provide the optimal user experience.
segment.target: A number of conditions must be met and steps followed to provide the optimal user experience.

segment.source: Use the information in the following section for more information:
segment.target: Use the information in the following section for more information:

segment.source: Usage Scenarios - As you review the two scenarios, keep in mind that these are the approach extremes.
segment.target: Usage Scenarios - As you review the two scenarios, keep in mind that these are the approach extremes.

segment.source: Based on your usage requirements, you may choose to apply these steps to a subset of users and/or virtual applications packages.
segment.target: Based on your usage requirements, you may choose to apply these steps to a subset of users and/or virtual applications packages.

segment.source: Optimized for Performance – To provide the optimal experience, you can expect the base image to include some of the App-V virtual application package.
segment.target: Optimized for Performance – To provide the optimal experience, you can expect the base image to include some of the App-V virtual application package.

segment.source: This and other requirements are discussed.
segment.target: This and other requirements are discussed.

segment.source: Optimized for Storage – If you are concerned with the storage impact, following this scenario will help address those concerns.
segment.target: Optimized for Storage – If you are concerned with the storage impact, following this scenario will help address those concerns.

segment.source: Preparing your Environment
segment.target: Preparing your Environment

segment.source: Steps to Prepare the Base Image – Whether in a non-persistent VDI or RDSH environment, only a few steps must be completed in the base image to enable this approach.
segment.target: Steps to Prepare the Base Image – Whether in a non-persistent VDI or RDSH environment, only a few steps must be completed in the base image to enable this approach.

segment.source: Use UE-V 2.0 as the User Profile Management (UPM) solution for the App-V approach – the cornerstone of this approach is the ability of a UEM solution to persist the contents of just a few registry and file locations.
segment.target: Use UE-V 2.0 as the User Profile Management (UPM) solution for the App-V approach – the cornerstone of this approach is the ability of a UEM solution to persist the contents of just a few registry and file locations.

segment.source: These locations constitute the user integrations.
segment.target: These locations constitute the user integrations.

segment.source: Be sure to review the specific requirements for the UPM solution.
segment.target: Be sure to review the specific requirements for the UPM solution.

segment.source: User Experience Walk-through
segment.target: User Experience Walk-through

segment.source: Walk-through – This is a step-by-step walk-through of the App-V and UE-V operations and the expectations users should have.
segment.target: Walk-through – This is a step-by-step walk-through of the App-V and UE-V operations and the expectations users should have.

segment.source: Outcome – This describes the expected results.
segment.target: Outcome – This describes the expected results.

segment.target: Impact to Package Lifecycle

segment.source: Enhancing the VDI Experience through Performance Optimization/Tuning
segment.target: Enhancing the VDI Experience through Performance Optimization/Tuning

segment.source: Applicability Checklist
segment.target: Applicability Checklist

segment.source: Deployment Environment
segment.target: Deployment Environment

segment.source: Non-Persistent VDI or RDSH.
segment.target: Non-Persistent VDI or RDSH.

segment.source: User Experience Virtualization (UE-V), other UPM solutions or User Profile Disks (UPD).
segment.target: User Experience Virtualization (UE-V), other UPM solutions or User Profile Disks (UPD).

segment.source: Expected Configuration
segment.target: Expected Configuration

segment.source: User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) with the App-V user state template enabled or User Profile Management (UPM) software.
segment.target: User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) with the App-V user state template enabled or User Profile Management (UPM) software.

segment.source: Non-UE-V UPM software must be capable of triggering on Login or Process/Application Start and Logoff.
segment.target: Non-UE-V UPM software must be capable of triggering on Login or Process/Application Start and Logoff.

segment.source: App-V Shared Content Store (SCS) is configured or can be configured.
segment.target: App-V Shared Content Store (SCS) is configured or can be configured.

segment.source: IT Administration
segment.target: IT Administration

segment.source: Admin may need to update the VM base image regularly to ensure optimal performance or Admin may need to manage multiple images for different user groups.
segment.target: Admin may need to update the VM base image regularly to ensure optimal performance or Admin may need to manage multiple images for different user groups.

segment.source: Usage Scenario
segment.target: Usage Scenario

segment.source: As you review the two scenarios, keep in mind that these approach the extremes.
segment.target: As you review the two scenarios, keep in mind that these approach the extremes.

segment.source: Based on your usage requirements, you may choose to apply these steps to a subset of users, virtual application packages, or both.
segment.target: Based on your usage requirements, you may choose to apply these steps to a subset of users, virtual application packages, or both.

segment.source: Optimized for Performance
segment.target: Optimized for Performance

segment.source: Optimized for Storage
segment.target: Optimized for Storage

segment.source: To provide the most optimal user experience, this approach leverages the capabilities of a UPM solution and requires additional image preparation and can incur some additional image management overhead.
segment.target: To provide the most optimal user experience, this approach leverages the capabilities of a UPM solution and requires additional image preparation and can incur some additional image management overhead.

segment.source: The following describes many performance improvements in stateful non-persistent deployments.
segment.target: The following describes many performance improvements in stateful non-persistent deployments.

segment.source: For more information, see the Sequencing Steps to Optimize Packages for Publishing Performance and reference to App-V 5.0 Sequencing Guide in the See Also section of this document.
segment.target: For more information, see the Sequencing Steps to Optimize Packages for Publishing Performance and reference to App-V 5.0 Sequencing Guide in the See Also section of this document.

segment.source: The general expectations of the previous scenario still apply here.
segment.target: The general expectations of the previous scenario still apply here.

segment.source: However, keep in mind that VM images are typically stored in very costly arrays; a slight alteration has been made to the approach.
segment.target: However, keep in mind that VM images are typically stored in very costly arrays; a slight alteration has been made to the approach.

segment.source: Do not pre-configure user-targeted virtual application packages in the base image.
segment.target: Do not pre-configure user-targeted virtual application packages in the base image.

segment.source: The impact of this alteration is detailed in the User Experience Walkthrough section of this document.
segment.target: The impact of this alteration is detailed in the User Experience Walkthrough section of this document.

segment.target: Preparing your Environment

segment.source: The following table displays the required steps to prepare the base image and the UE-V or another UPM solution for the approach.
segment.target: The following table displays the required steps to prepare the base image and the UE-V or another UPM solution for the approach.

segment.target: Prepare the Base Image

segment.source: Optimized for Performance
segment.target: Optimized for Performance

segment.target: Optimized for Storage

segment.source: Install the Hotfix Package 4 for Application Virtualization 5.0 SP2 client version of the client.
segment.target: Install the Hotfix Package 4 for Application Virtualization 5.0 SP2 client version of the client.

segment.source: Install UE-V and download the App-V Settings Template from the UE-V template Gallery, see the following steps.
segment.target: Install UE-V and download the App-V Settings Template from the UE-V template Gallery, see the following steps.

segment.source: Configure for Shared Content Store (SCS) mode.
segment.target: Configure for Shared Content Store (SCS) mode.

segment.source: For more information see How to Install the App-V 5.0 Client for Shared Content Store Mode.
segment.target: For more information see How to Install the App-V 5.0 Client for Shared Content Store Mode.

segment.source: Configure Preserve User Integrations on Login Registry DWORD.
segment.target: Configure Preserve User Integrations on Login Registry DWORD.

segment.source: Pre-configure all user- and global-targeted packages for example, Add-AppvClientPackage.
segment.target: Pre-configure all user- and global-targeted packages for example, Add-AppvClientPackage.

segment.source: Pre-configure all user- and global-targeted connection groups for example, Add-AppvClientConnectionGroup.
segment.target: Pre-configure all user- and global-targeted connection groups for example, Add-AppvClientConnectionGroup.

segment.source: Pre-publish all global-targeted packages.
segment.target: Pre-publish all global-targeted packages.

segment.source: Alternatively,
segment.target: Alternatively,

segment.source: Perform a global publishing/refresh.
segment.target: Perform a global publishing/refresh.

segment.source: Perform a user publishing/refresh.
segment.target: Perform a user publishing/refresh.

segment.source: Un-publish all user-targeted packages.
segment.target: Un-publish all user-targeted packages.

segment.source: Delete the following user-Virtual File System (VFS) entries.
segment.target: Delete the following user-Virtual File System (VFS) entries.

segment.source: Install the Hotfix Package 4 for Application Virtualization 5.0 SP2 client version of the client.
segment.target: Install the Hotfix Package 4 for Application Virtualization 5.0 SP2 client version of the client.

segment.source: Install UE-V and download the App-V Settings Template from the UE-V template Gallery, see the following steps.
segment.target: Install UE-V and download the App-V Settings Template from the UE-V template Gallery, see the following steps.

segment.source: Configure for Shared Content Store (SCS) mode.
segment.target: Configure for Shared Content Store (SCS) mode.

segment.source: For more information see How to Install the App-V 5.0 Client for Shared Content Store Mode.
segment.target: For more information see How to Install the App-V 5.0 Client for Shared Content Store Mode.

segment.source: Configure Preserve User Integrations on Login Registry DWORD.
segment.target: Configure Preserve User Integrations on Login Registry DWORD.

segment.source: Pre-configure all global-targeted packages for example, Add-AppvClientPackage.
segment.target: Pre-configure all global-targeted packages for example, Add-AppvClientPackage.

segment.target: Pre-configure all global-targeted connection groups for example, Add-AppvClientConnectionGroup.

segment.target: Pre-publish all global-targeted packages.

segment.source: Configurations - For critical App-V Client configurations and for a little more context and how-to, review the following information:
segment.target: Configurations - For critical App-V Client configurations and for a little more context and how-to, review the following information:

segment.source: Configuration Setting
segment.target: Configuration Setting

segment.source: What does this do?
segment.target: What does this do?

segment.source: How should I use it?
segment.target: How should I use it?

segment.source: Shared Content Store (SCS) Mode
segment.target: Shared Content Store (SCS) Mode

segment.source: Configurable in PowerShell using Set- AppvClientConfiguration –SharedContentStoreMode, or
segment.target: Configurable in PowerShell using Set- AppvClientConfiguration –SharedContentStoreMode, or

segment.source: During installation of the App-V 5.0 client.
segment.target: During installation of the App-V 5.0 client.

segment.source: When running the shared content store only publishing data is maintained on hard disk; other virtual application assets are maintained in memory (RAM).
segment.target: When running the shared content store only publishing data is maintained on hard disk; other virtual application assets are maintained in memory (RAM).

segment.source: This helps to conserve local storage and minimize disk I/O per second (IOPS).
segment.target: This helps to conserve local storage and minimize disk I/O per second (IOPS).

segment.source: This is recommended when low-latency connections are available between the App-V Client endpoint and the SCS content server, SAN.
segment.target: This is recommended when low-latency connections are available between the App-V Client endpoint and the SCS content server, SAN.

segment.source: PreserveUserIntegrationsOnLogin
segment.target: PreserveUserIntegrationsOnLogin

segment.source: Configure in the Registry under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESoftwareMicrosoftAppVClientIntegration.
segment.target: Configure in the Registry under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESoftwareMicrosoftAppVClientIntegration.

segment.source: Create the DWORD value PreserveUserIntegrationsOnLogin with a value of 1.
segment.target: Create the DWORD value PreserveUserIntegrationsOnLogin with a value of 1.

segment.source: Restart the App-V client service or restart the computer running the App-V Client.
segment.target: Restart the App-V client service or restart the computer running the App-V Client.

segment.source: If you have not pre-configured (Add-AppvClientPackage) a specific package and this setting is not configured, the App-V Client will de-integrate the persisted user integrations, then re-integrate.
segment.target: If you have not pre-configured (Add-AppvClientPackage) a specific package and this setting is not configured, the App-V Client will de-integrate the persisted user integrations, then re-integrate.

segment.source: For every package that meets the above conditions, effectively twice the work will be done during publishing/refresh.
segment.target: For every package that meets the above conditions, effectively twice the work will be done during publishing/refresh.

segment.source: If you don’t plan to pre-configure every available user package in the base image, use this setting.
segment.target: If you don’t plan to pre-configure every available user package in the base image, use this setting.

segment.source: MaxConcurrentPublishingRefresh
segment.target: MaxConcurrentPublishingRefresh

segment.source: Configure in the Registry under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESoftwareMicrosoftAppVClientPublishing.
segment.target: Configure in the Registry under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINESoftwareMicrosoftAppVClientPublishing.

segment.source: Create the DWORD value MaxConcurrentPublishingrefresh with the desired maximum number of concurrent publishing refreshes.
segment.target: Create the DWORD value MaxConcurrentPublishingrefresh with the desired maximum number of concurrent publishing refreshes.

segment.source: The App-V client service and computer do not need to be restarted.
segment.target: The App-V client service and computer do not need to be restarted.

segment.source: This setting determines the number of users that can perform a publishing refresh/sync at the same time.
segment.target: This setting determines the number of users that can perform a publishing refresh/sync at the same time.

segment.source: The default setting is no limit.
segment.target: The default setting is no limit.

segment.source: Limiting the number of concurrent publishing refreshes prevents excessive CPU usage that could impact computer performance.
segment.target: Limiting the number of concurrent publishing refreshes prevents excessive CPU usage that could impact computer performance.

segment.source: This limit is recommended in an RDS environment, where multiple users can log in to the same computer at the same time and perform a publishing refresh sync.
segment.target: This limit is recommended in an RDS environment, where multiple users can log in to the same computer at the same time and perform a publishing refresh sync.

segment.source: If the concurrent publishing refresh threshold is reached, the time required to publish new applications and make them available to end users after they log in could take an indeterminate amount of time.
segment.target: If the concurrent publishing refresh threshold is reached, the time required to publish new applications and make them available to end users after they log in could take an indeterminate amount of time.

segment.source: Configure UE-V solution for App-V Approach
segment.target: Configure UE-V solution for App-V Approach

segment.source: We recommend using Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) to capture and centralize application settings and Windows operating system settings for a specific user.
segment.target: We recommend using Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) to capture and centralize application settings and Windows operating system settings for a specific user.

segment.source: These settings are then applied to the different computers that are accessed by the user, including desktop computers, laptop computers, and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions.
segment.target: These settings are then applied to the different computers that are accessed by the user, including desktop computers, laptop computers, and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions.

segment.source: UE-V is optimized for RDS and VDI scenarios.
segment.target: UE-V is optimized for RDS and VDI scenarios.

segment.source: For more information see Getting Started With User Experience Virtualization 2.0
segment.target: For more information see Getting Started With User Experience Virtualization 2.0

segment.source: In essence all that is required is to install the UE-V client and download the following Microsoft authored App-V settings template from the Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) template gallery.
segment.target: In essence all that is required is to install the UE-V client and download the following Microsoft authored App-V settings template from the Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) template gallery.

segment.source: Register the template.
segment.target: Register the template.

segment.source: For more information around UE-V templates see The UE-V specific resource for acquiring and registering the template.
segment.target: For more information around UE-V templates see The UE-V specific resource for acquiring and registering the template.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Without performing an additional configuration step, the Microsoft User Environment Virtualization (UE-V) will not be able to synchronize the Start menu shortcuts (.lnk files) on the target computer.
segment.target: Without performing an additional configuration step, the Microsoft User Environment Virtualization (UE-V) will not be able to synchronize the Start menu shortcuts (.lnk files) on the target computer.

segment.source: The .lnk file type is excluded by default.
segment.target: The .lnk file type is excluded by default.

segment.source: UE-V will only support removing the .lnk file type from the exclusion list in the RDS and VDI scenarios, where every user’s device will have the same set of applications installed to the same location and every .lnk file is valid for all the users’ devices.
segment.target: UE-V will only support removing the .lnk file type from the exclusion list in the RDS and VDI scenarios, where every user’s device will have the same set of applications installed to the same location and every .lnk file is valid for all the users’ devices.

segment.source: For example, UE-V would not currently support the following 2 scenarios, because the net result will be that the shortcut will be valid on one but not all devices.
segment.target: For example, UE-V would not currently support the following 2 scenarios, because the net result will be that the shortcut will be valid on one but not all devices.

segment.source: If a user has an application installed on one device with .lnk files enabled and the same native application installed on another device to a different installation root with .lnk files enabled.
segment.target: If a user has an application installed on one device with .lnk files enabled and the same native application installed on another device to a different installation root with .lnk files enabled.

segment.source: If a user has an application installed on one device but not another with .lnk files enabled.
segment.target: If a user has an application installed on one device but not another with .lnk files enabled.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: This topic describes how to change the Windows registry by using Registry Editor.
segment.target: This topic describes how to change the Windows registry by using Registry Editor.

segment.source: If you change the Windows registry incorrectly, you can cause serious problems that might require you to reinstall Windows.
segment.target: If you change the Windows registry incorrectly, you can cause serious problems that might require you to reinstall Windows.

segment.source: You should make a backup copy of the registry files (System.dat and User.dat) before you change the registry.
segment.target: You should make a backup copy of the registry files (System.dat and User.dat) before you change the registry.

segment.source: Microsoft cannot guarantee that the problems that might occur when you change the registry can be resolved.
segment.target: Microsoft cannot guarantee that the problems that might occur when you change the registry can be resolved.

segment.source: Change the registry at your own risk.
segment.target: Change the registry at your own risk.

segment.source: Using the Microsoft Registry Editor (regedit.exe), navigate to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwareMicrosoftUEVAgentConfigurationExcludedFileTypes and remove .lnk from the excluded file types.
segment.target: Using the Microsoft Registry Editor (regedit.exe), navigate to HKEYLOCALMACHINESoftwareMicrosoftUEVAgentConfigurationExcludedFileTypes and remove .lnk from the excluded file types.

segment.source: Configure other User Profile Management (UPM) solution for App-V Approach
segment.target: Configure other User Profile Management (UPM) solution for App-V Approach

segment.source: The expectation in a stateful environment is that a UPM solution is implemented and can support persistence of user data across sessions and between logins.
segment.target: The expectation in a stateful environment is that a UPM solution is implemented and can support persistence of user data across sessions and between logins.

segment.source: The requirements for the UPM solution are as follows.
segment.target: The requirements for the UPM solution are as follows.

segment.source: To enable an optimized login experience, for example the App-V 5.0 approach for the user, the solution must be capable of:
segment.target: To enable an optimized login experience, for example the App-V 5.0 approach for the user, the solution must be capable of:

segment.source: Persisting the below user integrations as part of the user profile/persona.
segment.target: Persisting the below user integrations as part of the user profile/persona.

segment.source: Triggering a user profile sync on login (or application start), which can guarantee that all user integrations are applied before publishing/refresh begin, or,
segment.target: Triggering a user profile sync on login (or application start), which can guarantee that all user integrations are applied before publishing/refresh begin, or,

segment.source: Attaching and detaching a user profile disk (UPD) or similar technology that contains the user integrations.
segment.target: Attaching and detaching a user profile disk (UPD) or similar technology that contains the user integrations.

segment.source: Capturing changes to the locations, which constitute the user integrations, prior to session logoff.
segment.target: Capturing changes to the locations, which constitute the user integrations, prior to session logoff.

segment.source: With App-V 5.0 when you add a publishing server (Add-AppvPublishingServer) you can configure synchronization, for example refresh during log on and/or after a specified refresh interval.
segment.target: With App-V 5.0 when you add a publishing server (Add-AppvPublishingServer) you can configure synchronization, for example refresh during log on and/or after a specified refresh interval.

segment.source: In both cases a scheduled task is created.
segment.target: In both cases a scheduled task is created.

segment.source: In previous versions of App-V 5.0, both scheduled tasks were configured using a VBScript that would initiate the user and global refresh.
segment.target: In previous versions of App-V 5.0, both scheduled tasks were configured using a VBScript that would initiate the user and global refresh.

segment.source: With Hotfix Package 4 for Application Virtualization 5.0 SP2 the user refresh on log on is initiated by SyncAppvPublishingServer.exe.
segment.target: With Hotfix Package 4 for Application Virtualization 5.0 SP2 the user refresh on log on is initiated by SyncAppvPublishingServer.exe.

segment.source: This change was introduced to provide UPM solutions a trigger process.
segment.target: This change was introduced to provide UPM solutions a trigger process.

segment.source: This process will delay the publish /refresh to allow the UPM solution to apply the user integrations.
segment.target: This process will delay the publish /refresh to allow the UPM solution to apply the user integrations.

segment.source: It will exit once the publishing/refresh is complete.
segment.target: It will exit once the publishing/refresh is complete.

segment.source: User Integrations
segment.target: User Integrations

segment.target: Registry – HKEYCURRENTUSER

segment.target: Path - SoftwareClasses

segment.target: Exclude: Local Settings, ActivatableClasses, AppX

segment.target: File Locations

segment.target: Root – “Environment Variable” APPDATA

segment.target: Path – MicrosoftAppVClientCatalog

segment.target: Root – “Environment Variable” APPDATA

segment.target: Path – MicrosoftAppVClientIntegration

segment.source: Root – “Environment Variable” APPDATA
segment.target: Root – “Environment Variable” APPDATA

segment.source: Path - MicrosoftWindowsStart MenuPrograms
segment.target: Path - MicrosoftWindowsStart MenuPrograms

segment.source: (To persist all desktop shortcuts, virtual and non-virtual)
segment.target: (To persist all desktop shortcuts, virtual and non-virtual)

segment.source: Root - “KnownFolder” {B4BFCC3A-DB2C-424C-B029-7FE99A87C641}FileMask - .lnk
segment.target: Root - “KnownFolder” {B4BFCC3A-DB2C-424C-B029-7FE99A87C641}FileMask - .lnk

segment.source: Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V)
segment.target: Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V)

segment.source: Additionally, we recommend using Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) to capture and centralize application settings and Windows operating system settings for a specific user.
segment.target: Additionally, we recommend using Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) to capture and centralize application settings and Windows operating system settings for a specific user.

segment.source: These settings are then applied to the different computers that are accessed by the user, including desktop computers, laptop computers, and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions.
segment.target: These settings are then applied to the different computers that are accessed by the user, including desktop computers, laptop computers, and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions.

segment.source: For more information see Getting Started With User Experience Virtualization 1.0 and Sharing Settings Location Templates with the UE-V Template Gallery.
segment.target: For more information see Getting Started With User Experience Virtualization 1.0 and Sharing Settings Location Templates with the UE-V Template Gallery.

segment.source: User Experience Walk-through
segment.target: User Experience Walk-through

segment.source: This following is a step-by-step walk-through of the App-V and UPM operations and the expectations users should expect.
segment.target: This following is a step-by-step walk-through of the App-V and UPM operations and the expectations users should expect.

segment.source: Optimized for Performance
segment.target: Optimized for Performance

segment.source: Optimized for Storage
segment.target: Optimized for Storage

segment.source: After implementing this approach in the VDI/RDSH environment, on first login,
segment.target: After implementing this approach in the VDI/RDSH environment, on first login,

segment.source: (Operation) A user-publishing/refresh is initiated.
segment.target: (Operation) A user-publishing/refresh is initiated.

segment.source: (Expectation) If this is the first time a user has published virtual applications (e.g. non-persistent), this will take the usual duration of a publishing/refresh.
segment.target: (Expectation) If this is the first time a user has published virtual applications (e.g. non-persistent), this will take the usual duration of a publishing/refresh.

segment.source: (Operation) After the publishing/refresh, the UPM solution captures the user integrations.
segment.target: (Operation) After the publishing/refresh, the UPM solution captures the user integrations.

segment.source: (Expectation) Depending on how the UPM solution is configured, this may occur as part of the logoff process.
segment.target: (Expectation) Depending on how the UPM solution is configured, this may occur as part of the logoff process.

segment.source: This will incur the same/similar overhead as persisting the user state.
segment.target: This will incur the same/similar overhead as persisting the user state.

segment.source: On subsequent logins:
segment.target: On subsequent logins:

segment.source: (Operation) UPM solution applies the user integrations to the system prior to publishing/refresh.
segment.target: (Operation) UPM solution applies the user integrations to the system prior to publishing/refresh.

segment.source: (Expectation) There will be shortcuts present on the desktop, or in the start menu, which work immediately.
segment.target: (Expectation) There will be shortcuts present on the desktop, or in the start menu, which work immediately.

segment.source: When the publishing/refresh completes (i.e., package entitlements change), some may go away.
segment.target: When the publishing/refresh completes (i.e., package entitlements change), some may go away.

segment.source: (Operation) Publishing/refresh will process un-publish and publish operations for changes in user package entitlements.
segment.target: (Operation) Publishing/refresh will process un-publish and publish operations for changes in user package entitlements.

segment.source: (Expectation) If there are no entitlement changes, publishing1 will complete in seconds.
segment.target: (Expectation) If there are no entitlement changes, publishing1 will complete in seconds.

segment.source: Otherwise, the publishing/refresh will increase relative to the number and complexity* of virtual applications
segment.target: Otherwise, the publishing/refresh will increase relative to the number and complexity* of virtual applications

segment.source: (Operation) UPM solution will capture user integrations again at logoff.
segment.target: (Operation) UPM solution will capture user integrations again at logoff.

segment.source: (Expectation) Same as previous.
segment.target: (Expectation) Same as previous.

segment.source: ¹ The publishing operation (Publish-AppVClientPackage) adds entries to the user catalog, maps entitlement to the user, identifies the local store, and finishes by completing any integration steps.
segment.target: ¹ The publishing operation (Publish-AppVClientPackage) adds entries to the user catalog, maps entitlement to the user, identifies the local store, and finishes by completing any integration steps.

segment.source: After implementing this approach in the VDI/RDSH environment, on first login,
segment.target: After implementing this approach in the VDI/RDSH environment, on first login,

segment.source: (Operation) A user-publishing/refresh is initiated.
segment.target: (Operation) A user-publishing/refresh is initiated.

segment.source: (Expectation)
segment.target: (Expectation)

segment.source: If this is the first time a user has published virtual applications (e.g., non-persistent), this will take the usual duration of a publishing/refresh.
segment.target: If this is the first time a user has published virtual applications (e.g., non-persistent), this will take the usual duration of a publishing/refresh.

segment.source: First and subsequent logins will be impacted by pre-configuring of packages (add/refresh).
segment.target: First and subsequent logins will be impacted by pre-configuring of packages (add/refresh).

segment.source: (Operation) After the publishing/refresh, the UPM solution captures the user integrations.
segment.target: (Operation) After the publishing/refresh, the UPM solution captures the user integrations.

segment.source: (Expectation) Depending on how the UPM solution is configured, this may occur as part of the logoff process.
segment.target: (Expectation) Depending on how the UPM solution is configured, this may occur as part of the logoff process.

segment.source: This will incur the same/similar overhead as persisting the user state
segment.target: This will incur the same/similar overhead as persisting the user state

segment.source: On subsequent logins:
segment.target: On subsequent logins:

segment.source: (Operation) UPM solution applies the user integrations to the system prior to publishing/refresh.
segment.target: (Operation) UPM solution applies the user integrations to the system prior to publishing/refresh.

segment.source: (Operation) Add/refresh must pre-configure all user targeted applications.
segment.target: (Operation) Add/refresh must pre-configure all user targeted applications.

segment.source: (Expectation)
segment.target: (Expectation)

segment.source: This may increase the time to application availability significantly (on the order of 10’s of seconds).
segment.target: This may increase the time to application availability significantly (on the order of 10’s of seconds).

segment.source: This will increase the publishing refresh time relative to the number and complexity* of virtual applications.
segment.target: This will increase the publishing refresh time relative to the number and complexity* of virtual applications.

segment.source: (Operation) Publishing/refresh will process un-publish and publish operations for changes to user package entitlements.
segment.target: (Operation) Publishing/refresh will process un-publish and publish operations for changes to user package entitlements.

segment.source: Outcome
segment.target: Outcome

segment.source: Outcome
segment.target: Outcome

segment.source: Because the user integrations are entirely preserved, there will be no work for example, integration for the publishing/refresh to complete.
segment.target: Because the user integrations are entirely preserved, there will be no work for example, integration for the publishing/refresh to complete.

segment.source: All virtual applications will be available within seconds of login.
segment.target: All virtual applications will be available within seconds of login.

segment.source: The publishing/refresh will process changes to the users entitled virtual applications which impacts the experience.
segment.target: The publishing/refresh will process changes to the users entitled virtual applications which impacts the experience.

segment.source: Because the add/refresh must re-configure all the virtual applications to the VM, the publishing refresh time on every login will be extended.
segment.target: Because the add/refresh must re-configure all the virtual applications to the VM, the publishing refresh time on every login will be extended.

segment.source: Impact to Package Life Cycle
segment.target: Impact to Package Life Cycle

segment.source: Upgrading a package is a crucial aspect of the package lifecycle.
segment.target: Upgrading a package is a crucial aspect of the package lifecycle.

segment.source: To help guarantee users have access to the appropriate upgraded (published) or downgraded (un-published) virtual application packages, it is recommended you update the base image to reflect these changes.
segment.target: To help guarantee users have access to the appropriate upgraded (published) or downgraded (un-published) virtual application packages, it is recommended you update the base image to reflect these changes.

segment.source: To understand why review the following section:
segment.target: To understand why review the following section:

segment.source: App-V 5.0 SP2 introduced the concept of pending states.
segment.target: App-V 5.0 SP2 introduced the concept of pending states.

segment.source: In the past,
segment.target: In the past,

segment.source: If an administrator changed entitlements or created a new version of a package (upgraded) and during a publishing/refresh that package was in-use, the un-publish or publish operation, respectively, would fail.
segment.target: If an administrator changed entitlements or created a new version of a package (upgraded) and during a publishing/refresh that package was in-use, the un-publish or publish operation, respectively, would fail.

segment.source: Now, if a package is in-use the operation will be pended.
segment.target: Now, if a package is in-use the operation will be pended.

segment.source: The un-publish and publish-pend operations will be processed on service restart or if another publish or un-publish command is issued.
segment.target: The un-publish and publish-pend operations will be processed on service restart or if another publish or un-publish command is issued.

segment.source: In the latter case, if the virtual application is in-use otherwise, the virtual application will remain in a pending state.
segment.target: In the latter case, if the virtual application is in-use otherwise, the virtual application will remain in a pending state.

segment.source: For globally published packages, a restart (or service restart) often needed.
segment.target: For globally published packages, a restart (or service restart) often needed.

segment.source: In a non-persistent environment, it is unlikely these pended operations will be processed.
segment.target: In a non-persistent environment, it is unlikely these pended operations will be processed.

segment.source: The pended operations, for example tasks are captured under HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftAppVClientPendingTasks.
segment.target: The pended operations, for example tasks are captured under HKEYCURRENTUSERSoftwareMicrosoftAppVClientPendingTasks.

segment.source: Although this location is persisted by the UPM solution, if it is not applied to the environment prior to log on, it will not be processed.
segment.target: Although this location is persisted by the UPM solution, if it is not applied to the environment prior to log on, it will not be processed.

segment.source: Sequencing Steps to Optimize Packages for Publishing Performance
segment.target: Sequencing Steps to Optimize Packages for Publishing Performance

segment.source: App-V 5.0 and App-V 5.0 SP2 provide significant value in their respective releases.
segment.target: App-V 5.0 and App-V 5.0 SP2 provide significant value in their respective releases.

segment.source: Several features facilitate new scenarios or enabled new customer deployment scenarios.
segment.target: Several features facilitate new scenarios or enabled new customer deployment scenarios.

segment.source: These following features can impact the performance of the publishing and launch operations.
segment.target: These following features can impact the performance of the publishing and launch operations.

segment.source: Step
segment.target: Step

segment.source: Consideration
segment.target: Consideration

segment.source: Benefits
segment.target: Benefits

segment.source: Tradeoffs
segment.target: Tradeoffs

segment.source: No Feature Block 1 (FB1, also known as Primary FB)
segment.target: No Feature Block 1 (FB1, also known as Primary FB)

segment.source: No FB1 means the application will launch immediately and stream fault (application requires file, DLL and must pull down over the network) during launch.If there are network limitations, FB1 will:
segment.target: No FB1 means the application will launch immediately and stream fault (application requires file, DLL and must pull down over the network) during launch.If there are network limitations, FB1 will:

segment.source: Reduce the number of stream faults and network bandwidth used when you launch an application for the first time.
segment.target: Reduce the number of stream faults and network bandwidth used when you launch an application for the first time.

segment.source: Delay launch until the entire FB1 has been streamed.
segment.target: Delay launch until the entire FB1 has been streamed.

segment.source: Stream faulting decreases the launch time.
segment.target: Stream faulting decreases the launch time.

segment.source: Virtual application packages with FB1 configured will need to be re-sequenced.
segment.target: Virtual application packages with FB1 configured will need to be re-sequenced.

segment.source: Removing FB1
segment.target: Removing FB1

segment.source: Removing FB1 does not require the original application installer.
segment.target: Removing FB1 does not require the original application installer.

segment.source: After completing the following steps, it is suggested that you revert the computer running the sequencer to a clean snapshot.
segment.target: After completing the following steps, it is suggested that you revert the computer running the sequencer to a clean snapshot.

segment.source: Sequencer UI - Create a New Virtual Application Package.
segment.target: Sequencer UI - Create a New Virtual Application Package.

segment.source: Complete the sequencing steps up to Customize - Streaming.
segment.target: Complete the sequencing steps up to Customize - Streaming.

segment.source: At the Streaming step, do not select Optimize the package for deployment over slow or unreliable network.
segment.target: At the Streaming step, do not select Optimize the package for deployment over slow or unreliable network.

segment.source: If desired, move on to Target OS.
segment.target: If desired, move on to Target OS.

segment.source: Modify an Existing Virtual Application Package
segment.target: Modify an Existing Virtual Application Package

segment.source: Complete the sequencing steps up to Streaming.
segment.target: Complete the sequencing steps up to Streaming.

segment.source: Do not select Optimize the package for deployment over a slow or unreliable network.
segment.target: Do not select Optimize the package for deployment over a slow or unreliable network.

segment.source: Move to Create Package.
segment.target: Move to Create Package.

segment.source: PowerShell - Update an Existing Virtual Application Package.
segment.target: PowerShell - Update an Existing Virtual Application Package.

segment.source: Open an elevated PowerShell session.
segment.target: Open an elevated PowerShell session.

segment.source: Import-module appvsequencer.
segment.target: Import-module appvsequencer.

segment.source: "C:PackagesMyPackage.appv" -Installer
segment.target: "C:PackagesMyPackage.appv" -Installer

segment.source: "C:PackageInstallPackageUpgrade.exe empty.exe" -OutputPath
segment.target: "C:PackageInstallPackageUpgrade.exe empty.exe" -OutputPath

segment.source: "C:UpgradedPackages"
segment.target: "C:UpgradedPackages"

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This cmdlet requires an executable (.exe) or batch file (.bat).
segment.target: This cmdlet requires an executable (.exe) or batch file (.bat).

segment.source: You must provide an empty (does nothing) executable or batch file.
segment.target: You must provide an empty (does nothing) executable or batch file.

segment.source: Step
segment.target: Step

segment.source: Considerations
segment.target: Considerations

segment.source: Benefits
segment.target: Benefits

segment.source: Tradeoffs
segment.target: Tradeoffs

segment.source: No SXS Install at Publish (Pre-Install SxS assemblies)
segment.target: No SXS Install at Publish (Pre-Install SxS assemblies)

segment.source: Virtual Application packages do not need to be re-sequenced.
segment.target: Virtual Application packages do not need to be re-sequenced.

segment.source: SxS Assemblies can remain in the virtual application package.
segment.target: SxS Assemblies can remain in the virtual application package.

segment.source: The SxS Assembly dependencies will not install at publishing time.
segment.target: The SxS Assembly dependencies will not install at publishing time.

segment.source: SxS Assembly dependencies must be pre-installed.
segment.target: SxS Assembly dependencies must be pre-installed.

segment.source: Creating a new virtual application package on the sequencer
segment.target: Creating a new virtual application package on the sequencer

segment.source: If, during sequencer monitoring, an SxS Assembly (such as a VC++ Runtime) is installed as part of an application’s installation, SxS Assembly will be automatically detected and included in the package.
segment.target: If, during sequencer monitoring, an SxS Assembly (such as a VC++ Runtime) is installed as part of an application’s installation, SxS Assembly will be automatically detected and included in the package.

segment.source: The administrator will be notified and will have the option to exclude the SxS Assembly.
segment.target: The administrator will be notified and will have the option to exclude the SxS Assembly.

segment.source: Client Side:
segment.target: Client Side:

segment.source: When publishing a virtual application package, the App-V 5.0 SP2 Client will detect if a required SxS dependency is already installed.
segment.target: When publishing a virtual application package, the App-V 5.0 SP2 Client will detect if a required SxS dependency is already installed.

segment.source: If the dependency is unavailable on the computer and it is included in the package, a traditional Windows Insataller (.msi) installation of the SxS assembly will be initiated.
segment.target: If the dependency is unavailable on the computer and it is included in the package, a traditional Windows Insataller (.msi) installation of the SxS assembly will be initiated.

segment.source: As previously documented, simply install the dependency on the computer running the client to ensure that the Windows Installer (.msi) installation will not occur.
segment.target: As previously documented, simply install the dependency on the computer running the client to ensure that the Windows Installer (.msi) installation will not occur.

segment.source: Step
segment.target: Step

segment.source: Considerations
segment.target: Considerations

segment.source: Benefits
segment.target: Benefits

segment.source: Tradeoffs
segment.target: Tradeoffs

segment.source: Selectively Employ Dynamic Configuration files
segment.target: Selectively Employ Dynamic Configuration files

segment.source: The App-V 5.0 client must parse and process these Dynamic Configuration files.
segment.target: The App-V 5.0 client must parse and process these Dynamic Configuration files.

segment.source: Be conscious of size and complexity (script execution, VREG inclusions/exclusions) of the file.
segment.target: Be conscious of size and complexity (script execution, VREG inclusions/exclusions) of the file.

segment.source: Numerous virtual application packages may already have User- or computer–specific dynamic configurations files.
segment.target: Numerous virtual application packages may already have User- or computer–specific dynamic configurations files.

segment.source: Publishing times will improve if these files are used selectively or not at all.
segment.target: Publishing times will improve if these files are used selectively or not at all.

segment.source: Virtual application packages would need to be reconfigured individually or via the App-V server management console to remove associated Dynamic Configuration files.
segment.target: Virtual application packages would need to be reconfigured individually or via the App-V server management console to remove associated Dynamic Configuration files.

segment.source: Disabling a Dynamic Configuration using Powershell
segment.target: Disabling a Dynamic Configuration using Powershell

segment.source: For already published packages, you can use without
segment.target: For already published packages, you can use without

segment.source: -DynamicDeploymentConfiguration parameter
segment.target: -DynamicDeploymentConfiguration parameter

segment.source: Similarly, when adding new packages using , do not use the
segment.target: Similarly, when adding new packages using , do not use the

segment.source: -DynamicDeploymentConfiguration parameter.
segment.target: -DynamicDeploymentConfiguration parameter.

segment.source: For documentation on How to Apply a Dynamic Configuration, see:
segment.target: For documentation on How to Apply a Dynamic Configuration, see:

segment.source: How to Apply the User Configuration File by Using PowerShell
segment.target: How to Apply the User Configuration File by Using PowerShell

segment.source: How to Apply the Deployment Configuration File by Using PowerShell
segment.target: How to Apply the Deployment Configuration File by Using PowerShell

segment.source: Step
segment.target: Step

segment.source: Considerations
segment.target: Considerations

segment.source: Benefits
segment.target: Benefits

segment.source: Tradeoffs
segment.target: Tradeoffs

segment.source: Account for Synchronous Script Execution during Package Lifecycle.
segment.target: Account for Synchronous Script Execution during Package Lifecycle.

segment.source: If script collateral is embedded in the package, Add (Powershell) may be significantly slower.
segment.target: If script collateral is embedded in the package, Add (Powershell) may be significantly slower.

segment.source: Running of scripts during virtual application launch (StartVirtualEnvironment, StartProcess) and/or Add+Publish will impact the perceived performance during one or more of these lifecycle operations.
segment.target: Running of scripts during virtual application launch (StartVirtualEnvironment, StartProcess) and/or Add+Publish will impact the perceived performance during one or more of these lifecycle operations.

segment.source: Use of Asynchronous (Non-Blocking) Scripts will ensure that the lifecycle operations complete efficiently.
segment.target: Use of Asynchronous (Non-Blocking) Scripts will ensure that the lifecycle operations complete efficiently.

segment.source: This step requires working knowledge of all virtual application packages with embedded script collateral, which have associated dynamic configurations files and which reference and run scripts synchronously.
segment.target: This step requires working knowledge of all virtual application packages with embedded script collateral, which have associated dynamic configurations files and which reference and run scripts synchronously.

segment.source: Remove Extraneous Virtual Fonts from Package.
segment.target: Remove Extraneous Virtual Fonts from Package.

segment.source: The majority of applications investigated by the App-V product team contained a small number of fonts, typically fewer than 20.
segment.target: The majority of applications investigated by the App-V product team contained a small number of fonts, typically fewer than 20.

segment.source: Virtual Fonts impact publishing refresh performance.
segment.target: Virtual Fonts impact publishing refresh performance.

segment.source: Desired fonts will need to be enabled/installed natively.
segment.target: Desired fonts will need to be enabled/installed natively.

segment.source: For instructions, see Install or uninstall fonts.
segment.target: For instructions, see Install or uninstall fonts.

segment.source: Determining what virtual fonts exist in the package
segment.target: Determining what virtual fonts exist in the package

segment.source: Make a copy of the package.
segment.target: Make a copy of the package.

segment.source: Rename Packagecopy.appv to Packagecopy.zip
segment.target: Rename Packagecopy.appv to Packagecopy.zip

segment.source: Open AppxManifest.xml and locate the following:
segment.target: Open AppxManifest.xml and locate the following:

segment.source: appv:Extension Category="AppV.Fonts"
segment.target: appv:Extension Category="AppV.Fonts"

segment.source: appv:Fonts
segment.target: appv:Fonts

segment.source: appv:Font Path="{Fonts}privateCalibriL.ttf" DelayLoad="true"/appv:Font
segment.target: appv:Font Path="{Fonts}privateCalibriL.ttf" DelayLoad="true"/appv:Font

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If there are fonts marked as DelayLoad, those will not impact first launch.
segment.target: If there are fonts marked as DelayLoad, those will not impact first launch.

segment.source: /appv:Fonts
segment.target: /appv:Fonts

segment.source: Excluding virtual fonts from the package
segment.target: Excluding virtual fonts from the package

segment.source: Use the dynamic configuration file that best suits the user scope – deployment configuration for all users on computer, user configuration for specific user or users.
segment.target: Use the dynamic configuration file that best suits the user scope – deployment configuration for all users on computer, user configuration for specific user or users.

segment.source: Disable fonts with the deployment or user configuration.
segment.target: Disable fonts with the deployment or user configuration.

segment.source: Fonts
segment.target: Fonts

segment.source: Fonts Enabled="false" /
segment.target: Fonts Enabled="false" /

segment.source: App-V 5.0 Performance Guidance Terminology
segment.target: App-V 5.0 Performance Guidance Terminology

segment.source: The following terms are used when describing concepts and actions related to App-V 5.0 performance optimization.
segment.target: The following terms are used when describing concepts and actions related to App-V 5.0 performance optimization.

segment.source: Complexity – Refers to the one or more package characteristics that may impact performance during pre-configure (Add-AppvClientPackage) or integration (Publish-AppvClientPackage).
segment.target: Complexity – Refers to the one or more package characteristics that may impact performance during pre-configure (Add-AppvClientPackage) or integration (Publish-AppvClientPackage).

segment.source: Some example characteristics are: manifest size, number of virtual fonts, number of files.
segment.target: Some example characteristics are: manifest size, number of virtual fonts, number of files.

segment.source: De-Integrate – Removes the user integrations
segment.target: De-Integrate – Removes the user integrations

segment.source: Re-Integrate – Applies the user integrations.
segment.target: Re-Integrate – Applies the user integrations.

segment.source: Non-Persistent, Pooled – Creates a computer running a virtual environment each time they log in.
segment.target: Non-Persistent, Pooled – Creates a computer running a virtual environment each time they log in.

segment.source: Persistent, Personal – A computer running a virtual environment that remains the same for every login.
segment.target: Persistent, Personal – A computer running a virtual environment that remains the same for every login.

segment.source: Stateful - For this document, implies that user integrations are persisted between sessions and a user environment management technology is used in conjunction with non-persistent RDSH or VDI.
segment.target: Stateful - For this document, implies that user integrations are persisted between sessions and a user environment management technology is used in conjunction with non-persistent RDSH or VDI.

segment.source: Stateless – Represents a scenario when no user state is persisted between sessions.
segment.target: Stateless – Represents a scenario when no user state is persisted between sessions.

segment.source: Trigger – (or Native Action Triggers).
segment.target: Trigger – (or Native Action Triggers).

segment.source: UPM uses these types of triggers to initiate monitoring or synchronization operations.
segment.target: UPM uses these types of triggers to initiate monitoring or synchronization operations.

segment.source: User Experience - In the context of App-V 5.0, the user experience, quantitatively, is the sum of the following parts:
segment.target: User Experience - In the context of App-V 5.0, the user experience, quantitatively, is the sum of the following parts:

segment.source: From the point that users initiate a log-in to when they are able to manipulate the desktop.
segment.target: From the point that users initiate a log-in to when they are able to manipulate the desktop.

segment.source: From the point where the desktop can be interacted with to the point a publishing refresh begins (in PowerShell terms, sync) when using the App-V 5.0 full server infrastructure.
segment.target: From the point where the desktop can be interacted with to the point a publishing refresh begins (in PowerShell terms, sync) when using the App-V 5.0 full server infrastructure.

segment.source: In standalone instances, it is when the Add-AppVClientPackage and Publish-AppVClientPackage Powershell commands are initiated.
segment.target: In standalone instances, it is when the Add-AppVClientPackage and Publish-AppVClientPackage Powershell commands are initiated.

segment.source: From start to completion of the publishing refresh.
segment.target: From start to completion of the publishing refresh.

segment.source: In standalone instances, this is the first to last virtual application published.
segment.target: In standalone instances, this is the first to last virtual application published.

segment.source: From the point where the virtual application is available to launch from a shortcut.
segment.target: From the point where the virtual application is available to launch from a shortcut.

segment.source: Alternatively, it is from the point at which the file type association is registered and will launch a specified virtual application.
segment.target: Alternatively, it is from the point at which the file type association is registered and will launch a specified virtual application.

segment.source: User Profile Management – The controlled and structured approach to managing user components associated with the environment.
segment.target: User Profile Management – The controlled and structured approach to managing user components associated with the environment.

segment.source: For example, user profiles, preference and policy management, application control and application deployment.
segment.target: For example, user profiles, preference and policy management, application control and application deployment.

segment.source: You can use scripting or third-party solutions configure the environment as needed.
segment.target: You can use scripting or third-party solutions configure the environment as needed.

segment.source: Got a suggestion for App-V?
segment.target: Got a suggestion for App-V?

segment.source: Add or vote on suggestions here.
segment.target: Add or vote on suggestions here.

segment.source: For App-V issues, use the App-V TechNet Forum.
segment.target: For App-V issues, use the App-V TechNet Forum.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Microsoft Application Virtualization 5.0 Administrator's Guide
